subsection.title: Product and Quotient Rules
subsection.p: Radicals with the same value may be written in different forms. Consider the following calculation: \left(2\sqrt{2}\right)^2 \amp = 2^2\left(\sqrt{2}\right)^2~~~~~~~~\blert{\text{By the fourth law of exponents.}} \amp = 4(2)=8 This calculation shows that 2\sqrt{2} is equal to \sqrt{8}, because the square of 2\sqrt{2} is 8. You can verify on your calculator that 2\sqrt{2} and \sqrt{8} have the same decimal approximation, 2.828.

statement.p: Show that ~~\sqrt{45} = 3\sqrt{5}.

solution.p: \sqrt{45} is a number whose square is 45. We can square 3\sqrt{5} as follows: (3\sqrt{5})^2 \amp = 3^2(\sqrt{5})^2 \amp = 9(5)=45 Because the square of 3\sqrt{5} is equal to 45, it is the case that 3\sqrt{5}=\sqrt{45}.

subsection.p: It is usually helpful to write a radical expression as simply as possible. The expression 2\sqrt{2} is considered simpler than \sqrt{8}, because the radicand is a smaller number. Similarly, 3\sqrt{5} is simpler than \sqrt{45}. In this section we discover properties of radicals that help us simplify radical expressions.
In the Activities we will verify the following properties of radicals.

statement.p:
Decide which statement is true and which is false.
\sqrt{4} + \sqrt{9} = \sqrt{13}?
\sqrt{4}\sqrt{9} = \sqrt{36}?

li.p: \sqrt{4} + \sqrt{9} = 2+3 = 5, but \sqrt{13} \not= 5, so the first statement is false.
\sqrt{4}\sqrt{9} = 2(3) = 6, and \sqrt{36} = 6, so the second statement is true.

subsection.title: Simplifying Square Roots
subsection.p: We can use the product rule for radicals to write \sqrt{12} = \sqrt{4}\sqrt{3}. Now, \sqrt{4}=2, so we can simplify \sqrt{12} as \sqrt{12} = \sqrt{4}\sqrt{3} = 2\sqrt{3}

The expression 2\sqrt{3} is a simplified form for \sqrt{12}. The factor of 4, which is a perfect square, has been removed from the radical. This example illustrates a strategy for simplifying radicals.

Use the product rule to write the radical as a product of two square roots.
Simplify the square root of the perfect square.

statement.p: Simplify ~\sqrt{45}.

warning.p: Finding a decimal approximation for a radical is not the same as simplifying the radical. In , we can use a calculator to find \sqrt{45} \approx 6.708 but 6.708 is not the exact value for \sqrt{45}. For long calculations, too much accuracy may be lost by approximating each radical. However, 3\sqrt{5} is equivalent to \sqrt{45}, which means that their values are exactly the same. We can replace one expression by the other without losing accuracy.

statement.p: What is the difference between simplifying a square root and approximating a square root?

answer.p: Simplifying a square root gives an equivalent expression.

subsection.title: Square Root of a Variable Expression

statement.p: If x is a nonnegative number, \sqrt{x^{10}} = x^5~~~~~\text{because}~~~~~~(x^5)^2 = x^{10} Similarly, if a is not negative, \sqrt{a^6} = a^3~~~~~\text{because}~~~~~~(a^3)^2 = a^6
How do we simplify the square root of a variable raised to an even exponent?

subsection.p: For the rest of this section we'll assume that all variables are nonnegative.

warning.p: Note that \sqrt{a^{16}} is not equal to a^4. Compare the two radicals: \sqrt{16} = 4 ~~~~~~\text{but}~~~~~~ \sqrt{a^{16}} = a^8

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: How can we simplify the square root of an odd power? We write the power as a product of two factors, one having an even exponent and one having exponent 1.

statement.p: Simplify ~~\sqrt{x^7}
How do we simplify the square root of a variable raised to an odd exponent?

answer.p: Write the power as a product of two factors, one having an even exponent and one having exponent 1.

subsection.p: If the radicand contains more than one variable or a coefficient, we consider the constants and each variable separately. We try to remove the largest factors possible from the radicand.

subsection.title: Sums and Differences
subsection.p: What about sums and differences of radicals? We cannot add or subtract radicals by combining their radicands. That is, \alert{\sqrt{a} + \sqrt{b} \not= \sqrt{a+b}}

So, we cannot simplify a sum or difference if the expressions under the radical are different. However, we can combine radicals with the same radicand. For example, we can write \sqrt{7}+\sqrt{7} = 2\sqrt{7} just as we write x+x=2x

assemblage.title: Like Radicals
assemblage.p: Square roots with identical radicands are called like radicals.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: We can add or subtract like radicals in the same way that we add or subtract like terms, namely by adding or subtracting their coefficients. For example, 2r+3r=5r where r is a variable that can stand for any real number. In particular, if r=\sqrt{2}, we have 2\sqrt{2}+3\sqrt{2} = 5\sqrt{2} Thus, we may add like radicals by adding their coefficients. The same idea applies to subtraction.

statement.p: What are like radicals?

ol.label: a

li.p: Because 7\sqrt{3} and 2\sqrt{3} are like radicals, we can combine them as 7\sqrt{3}-2\sqrt{3} = 5\sqrt{3}

ol.li: However, 3\sqrt{2} and 4\sqrt{3} are not like radicals. We cannot simplify sums or differences of unlike radicals. Thus, 3\sqrt{2}+4\sqrt{3} cannot be combined into a single term.

statement.p: How do we add or subtract like radicals?

answer.p: By adding or subtracting their coefficients
